questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with fever, sore throat, malaise and vesicles on the hands, feet, and painful oral ulcers. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness usually affecting infants and children under 10year.
  • HFMD involves the hands, feet, mouth. Vesicles is surrounded by a thin halo of erythema, eventually rupturing and forming superficial ulcers with a grey-yellow base and erythematous rim.
  • Cause: MC - coxsackievirus A16 and enterovirus71 in most cases, many other strains of coxsackievirus.
  • Spread - oral ingestion of the shed virus from the gastrointestinal or upper respiratory tract of infected hosts or via vesicle fluid or oral secretions.
  • Treatment is mostly supportive and symptomatic. In severe cases, if neurological complications occur, intravenous immunoglobulin is advisable.

Vesicles in HFMD

Explanation for other options:

  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-1)(Option A) it can causes herpetic gingivostomatitis, which affects the mouth only, no rash on hands/feet.
  • Parvovirus B19 infection(Option B): Causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), not HFMD. Presents with a "slapped cheek" rash and lacy exanthem on the trunk and limbs.
  • Epstein-Barr virus infection(Option D): Causes infectious mononucleosis, with pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly, but no vesicular rash on hands/feet.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents with multiple painful grouped vesicles on an erythematous base over the lips as shown in the image. A Tzanck smear prepared from the base of the vesicle shows multinucleated giant cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • The given Image shows grouped vesicles on lip margin with erythematous base s/o herpes labialis caused by Herpes simplex.
  • Herpes labialis is a mild, self-limiting infection with herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1).
  • It causes pain and blistering on the lips and perioral area (cold sores); fever and constitutional symptoms are rare
  • Primary infection usually occurs in childhood, after which the virus is thought to remain latent in the trigeminal ganglion.
  • Recurrence may be triggered by factors such as exposure to bright light, stress, and fatigue.
  • A Tzanck smear is a cytologic technique commonly used in the diagnosis of herpes virus infections (simplex, genitalis, varicella-zoster).
    • An early vesicle is deroofed, and the base of the lesion is scraped gently with a scalpel blade. The material is then placed on a glass slide, air-dried, and stained with Giemsa stain.
    • Multinucleated giant cells suggest the presence of herpes.
    • Another finding - presence of acantholytic cells
  • Treatment is with antiviral like acyclovir.

Multinucleated syncitial giant cells of herpes

Explanation of other options:

Pemphigoid(Option B): Tzanck smear does not show multinucleated giant cells; instead, it is characterized histologically by subepidermal blistering with eosinophils.

Molluscum contagiosum(Option C): Shows large intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies (Henderson–Paterson bodies) in infected keratinocytes, not multinucleated giant cells.

Pemphigus(Option D) :Tzanck smear reveals acantholytic cells (detached, rounded keratinocytes), but multinucleated giant cells are not a feature.

questions.text: Which of the following does not present with vesicular skin lesions?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer

  • Measles (Rubeola) presents with a maculopapular rash, not vesicles.
  • The typical erythematous, non-pruritic, blotchy maculopapular rash of measles begins at the hairline and behind the ears. It then spreads down the trunk and limbs to include the palms and soles, and becomes confluent.
  • This rash develops in a person with a prodrome of cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis (the 3 C's).
  • Koplik spots are usually present on the buccal mucosa opposite the premolar teeth bluish-white spots with bright red areolae.

Viral exanthems

questions.text: Match the following dermatological conditions with their characteristic histopathological findings:
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Molluscum contagiosum: Shows large intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies in (Henderson-Paterson bodies) keratinocytes.
  • Bullous impetigo: Subcorneal split filled with neutrophils and cocci - caused by Staph. aureus producing exfoliative toxin.
  • Herpes zoster: Ballooning degeneration of keratinocytes, multinucleated giant cells, and acantholysis.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris: Suprabasal acantholysis, "row of tombstones" basal layer.

Row of toombstone

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a history of painful vesicular rash over the right thoracic dermatome that resolved 5 weeks ago. However, he continues to experience burning and stabbing pain in the same area. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Post-herpetic neuralgia is defined as the persistence or recurrence of pain more than a month after the onset of zoster, but is better considered after 3 months.
  • Herpes zoster (Shingles) is caused by reactivation of a latent varicella zoster virus in the sensory nerve ganglion.
  • More common is elderly / immunosuppression.
  • It is a type of allodynia(pain caused by normally innocuous stimuli)
  • Post-herpetic neuralgia could last for 3 months or longer.

questions.text: The following Image shows:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given image visualisation of thrombosed capillaries (black dots) and pinpoint bleeding along with the loss of normal dermatoglyphics, differentiates a plantar wart from other cutaneous lesions, such as calluses or corns
  • Plantar warts are cutaneous lesions on the plantar aspect of the foot that are caused by the infection of keratinocytes with the human papillomavirus(HPV) most commonly by HPV-1.
  • Plantar warts may appear as a singular rough, flesh-colored to yellow or grey-brown, hyperkeratotic papule,
  • On palpation, plantar warts feel rough and are tender when squeezed along the sides.
  • Myrmecia is a specific type of plantar wart caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV) type 1. It is characterized by its deep penetration into the skin and is often painful due to its location on pressure-bearing areas of the foot.
  • Mosaic warts are characterized by a confluent plaque composed of numerous small warts, often forming rough, thickened skin resembling a mosaic floor. They are mostly caused by HPV type 2.

Explanation of other options:

Corn (Option A)is a localized, painful, cone-shaped thickening of the stratum corneum over pressure points, often with a central core.

Callus(Option B)is a diffuse, painless area of thickened skin resulting from repeated friction or pressure, without a central core.

questions.text: A baby presented with fever and rash, as shown in the image. Which of the following condition is NOT caused by virus that causes this disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The given Image shows bilateral erythematous rash on cheeks, slapped cheek appearance. Seen in Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease)
  • This is caused by the human parvovirus B19.
  • A slapped cheek erythema is quickly followed by a reticulate erythema on the trunk.
  • Other diseases caused by parvovirus b19 - Fetal hydrops(Option C ruled out), Aplastic anemia in sickle cell disease(Option B ruled out), chronic anemia in transplant patients, acute symmetric polyarthropathy in normal adults
  • Roseola infantum or exanthema subitum is the most common exanthematic fever in children under the age of 2 years.
  • It is caused by HHV-6 and HHV-7 .
  • It is also called the 6th disease.
  • Child presents with fever and maculopapular eruption over neck and trunk region.
  • Nagayama spots are red papules over the palate are pathognomic.

questions.text: A HIV patient presented with an asymptomatic white lesion on the side of the tongue, which cannot be rubbed off. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The diagnosis is Oral hairy leukoplakia, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus
  • The image shows a white plaque on side of tongue, with feathery margins and a corrugated surface. The plaque cannot be scraped off, which differentiates it from oral candidiasis.
  • This is usually an asymptomatic disease.
  • In a patient of HIV, it usually indicative of fairly advanced immunologic decline, generally occurring in patients with less than 300 CD4+ T cells per microliter.
  • It responds to HAART.

Explanation of other options

  • Candidiasis(Option B): White, scrapable plaques caused by Candida species.
  • Oral Lichen Planus(Option C): it is an autoimmune mucocutaneous disease which presents with white reticular or plaque-like lesions, commonly bilateral and on buccal mucosa or tongue.
  • Diphtheria (option D): Gray-white pseudomembrane in the upper respiratory tract ( mostly tonsils, larynx, pharynx)that bleeds on removal, caused by C. diphtheriae.

Pseudomembrane formed by Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.text: A child of 10 years presents with multiple similar papular lesions arranged linearly on areas of trauma, following scratching. These lesions appear to have spread from a primary viral lesion. What is the most likely phenomenon depicted?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The phenomenon observed here is Pseudo isomorphic phenomenon where lesions appear along the line of trauma due to auto-inoculation of the infectious agent.Verruca (Warts) and Molluscum Contagiosum are conditions where pseudo-isomorphic phenomenon is observed.
  • Multiple hyperpigmented flat topped papules, with verrucous surface, discrete as well coalescent, suggestive of Diagnosis as verruca plana.

Explanation of other options:

  • Isomorphic phenomenon (Koebner phenomenon)(Option A): development of lesions identical to a patient's existing dermatosis (e.g., psoriasis, lichen planus, vitiligo) at sites of skin injury.
  • Meyerson's phenomenon(Option C): an eczematous halo (red, scaling, often itchy) that develops surrounding a preexisting lesion, such as a nevus or other cutaneous growth
  • Nikolsky sign(Option D): the ability to dislodge or shear off the superficial epidermis with lateral pressure, indicating a plane of cleavage within the epidermis, classically positive in pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented with lesions on the face for the last 3 months. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The image shows multiple small, flesh-colored to pearly, dome-shaped papules with a central umbilicated (dimpled) center characteristic of a molluscum contagiosum infection.
  • Molluscum contagiosum virus causes characteristic skin lesions consisting of single or, more often, multiple, dome-shaped, pearly white umbilicated papules.
  • Molluscum contagiosum is a viral disease caused by a Molluscipox virus, dsDNA poxvirus
  • MCV-1 is responsible for the majority of infections in children.
  • MCV-2 has a stronger association with adult genital lesions and HIV-positive individuals.
  • In molluscum contagiosum, lesions may appear in a linear distribution or along scratch marks.This occurs because the virus gets auto-inoculated from existing lesions into adjacent traumatized skin (e.g., during scratching). It is known as Pseudo Koebner phenomenon.
  • The hallmark finding on histopathological examination of molluscum contagiosum is the presence of:
    • Molluscum (Henderson-Patterson) bodies:
      • These are large eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies.
      • Found in the stratum spinosum and stratum granulosum of the epidermis.
  • Treatment :self-limited and heals spontaneously in 6-9 months
  • Although treatment is not required, it may help to reduce autoinoculation or transmission to close contacts and improve clinical appearance - cryotherapy or curettage

questions.text: A 30-year-old sheep farmer presents with a solitary, firm, erythematous papule on the dorsum of his hand. Over the next few days, the lesion enlarges into a nodular lesion with a central umbilication and crust, but is painless. He reports recent handling of lambs during the birthing season. There is no systemic involvement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The clinical scenario describes a painless, firm nodular lesion with central umbilication and crust, following contact with sheep or lambs this is classic for Orf, also known as Ecthyma contagiosum.
  • Orf is a zoonotic parapoxvirus infection acquired from handling sheep or goats, particularly around lambing.
  • Lesion progression: macule → papule → nodular lesion with umbilication and crust.
  • It is self-limiting and typically resolves in 4-6 weeks without scarring.

Explanation of other options:

Milker's nodule(Option A): It is Caused by a different parapoxvirus from infected cows (not sheep)

Lesions look similar but occur in dairy farm workers, not sheep handlers.

Cutaneous anthrax(Option B):Presents with a painless ulcer with a black eschar and significant edema around it.Often associated with exposure to infected animal hides or meat.

Sporotrichosis(Option D):Fungal infection from rose thorns or soil (not lambs)

Presents with nodular lymphangitis multiple nodules along lymphatics, unlike the solitary lesion here.

questions.text: A 27-year-old sexually active male presents with multiple painless, soft, warty, sessile growths over the external genitalia. The lesions are skin-colored to pink, with a cauliflower-like surface. There is no history of ulceration or systemic symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In the given clinical scenario, there are multiple painless, soft, wart-like lesions over the external genitalia. Given the clinical history of sexual activity and the characteristic cauliflower-like, exophytic warty lesions, it is most likely a case of condylomata acuminata, which refers to anogenital warts caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV).
  • The most common strains of HPV that cause anogenital warts are 6 and 11.
  • HPV is a double-stranded DNA virus primarily spread through sexual contact.
  • Lesions are generally found in multiples and can coalesce into larger lesions.
  • Condyloma acuminata usually appear as raised, skin-colored, fleshy papules that range in size from one to five millimeters in diameter. They can be broad and flat, pedicled, or occasionally have a cauliflower-like appearance

Explanation of other options:

  • Verruca Vulgaris(Option B): Common warts caused by HPV types 2 and 4. They are most commonly found on hands, fingers, knees
    • Appearance: Firm, hyperkeratotic, dome-shaped papules with rough surface.Not typically found on genitalia.
  • Filiform Warts(Option C) :Warts that are finger-like or thread-like projections.Usually seen on face, eyelids, neck, lips.The image shows broad-based cauliflower-like lesions, not filiform projections.
  • Periungual Warts(Option D): Warts that occur around or under the fingernails or toenails

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented with history of HIV and painful violaceous over the hard lesions on palate as shown below. There is no history of trauma or any dental procedures. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Kaposi sarcoma occurs in patients with immunosuppression likeAIDs / organ transplant
  • Human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8) is present in all forms of Kaposi sarcoma
  • Clinically, Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular lesion, and presents as a violaceous pink to purple plaque on the skin or mucocutaneous surfaces.
  • HPE - spindle cell proliferation of irregular, complex vascular channels dissecting through the dermis with the promontory sign, defined as ramifying proliferating vessels surrounding larger ecstatic pre-existing vessels and skin adnexa.
  • Immunohistochemistry positivity for LANA1 +

questions.text: Which of the following dermatomes is most commonly involved in Herpes Zoster infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Herpes Zoster (Shingles) is caused by reactivation of latent Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) in the dorsal root ganglia.
    • It most commonly involves a single dermatome (unilateral) and presents as painful vesicular rash.
    • Thoracic dermatomes (especially T3-T12) are most frequently affected (~50-60% of cases).. Sensory nerves are primarily affected; motor or autonomic involvement is rare.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presented with lesions on hand as shown. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario the image shows multiple hyperkeratotic, dome-shaped papules on the fingers, typical of common warts (verruca vulgaris).
  • Warts are benign epithelial proliferations associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.
  • Warts are transmitted by direct contact and infect exclusively epithelial cells of the skin or mucous membranes.
  • Certain HPV types tend to infect skin at particular anatomic sites; however, warts of any HPV type may occur at any site
  • Myrmecia wart, or deep palmoplantar wart are sharply defined painful keratotic papules mostly caused by HPV-1

questions.text: All of the following are drugs used in the management of verruca vulgaris except ?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer

  • Verruca vulgaris (common warts) is caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV), primarily types 2 and 4. The treatment options are aimed at destruction of the wart tissue or immunomodulation. Acyclovir, which is an antiviral agent used against Herpes viruses, has no role in treating HPV-induced warts.
  • Salicylic acid is a first-line therapy used to treat warts.
  • Others topical medications- Cantharidin, Trichloroacetic acid
  • Oral medication - Retinoids
  • Surgical - Cryosurgery(Liquid nitrogen (-196°C)), Carbon dioxide lasers, electrodesiccation and curettage,

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with severe ear pain and multiple painful vesicles on the external ear and auditory canal as shown in the image. He also has facial asymmetry and an inability to close the eye on the same side. On examination, there is ipsilateral lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy with a vesicular rash over the pinna. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The given image shows vesicular lesions and crusting on the auricle (pinna) and external auditory canal, with involvement of the adjacent facial skin also the patient has severe ear pain and facial asymmetry which are classical presentation in Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.
  • Ramsay Hunt Syndrome (Herpes zoster oticus) is caused by reactivation of varicella-zoster virus in the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve (CN VII).
  • The classic triad of Ramsay Hunt Syndrome (Herpes Zoster Oticus) includes:
    • Ipsilateral facial paralysis (Lower Motor Neuron type - involves forehead)
    • Vesicular rash in the external ear, pinna, or auditory canal
    • Ear pain (otalgia)
  • Other features:
    • Hearing loss
    • Vertigo
    • Tinnitus
    • Altered taste on the anterior 2/3 of the tongue (via chorda tympani)
    • Dry mouth or eyes
  • Treatment:
    • Antivirals: Oral acyclovir 800 mg 5×/day for 7-10 days, or equivalent valacyclovir/famciclovir
    • Steroids: Oral prednisone 1 mg/kg/day (up to ~60 mg) with taper over approximately 10 days
    • Timing: Critical-best outcomes if started within 72 hours of symptom onset

Explanation of other options:

Bell's Palsy(Option A): An isolated lower motor neuron facial palsy without any rash. It's idiopathic and usually painless. The presence of vesicles in the image rules this out.

Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus (Option B): It is caused by reactivation of Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) in the ophthalmic (V1) division of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V).

Key Clinical Features :Painful vesicular rash over the forehead, upper eyelid, and scalp, in the distribution of the ophthalmic nerve.

Hutchinson's sign: Vesicles on the tip or side of the nose (nasociliary branch involvement) → indicates high risk of ocular involvement.

May lead to keratitis, conjunctivitis, uveitis, or vision loss.

Facial palsy is not typical (helps differentiate from Ramsay Hunt Syndrome).

Otitis Externa(Option D): A bacterial or fungal infection of the external ear canal. Presents with pain, swelling, and discharge, but not vesicular rash or facial palsy.
